Speaker.P: The grade of student nurse is a training grade and accordingly all students are employed on a temporary basis for the duration of their training.

The numbers of student nurses in training at any time is determined having regard to future service needs and the capacity of training schools. This number is kept under constant review both by my Department and by An Bord Altranais which has statutory responsibilities for the training of nurses.

Qst.Quest: if he proposes to set up a statutory body to oversee the ambulance service to ensure that there is a uniformity of standards throughout the health board regions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The provision of ambulance services is a matter for each health board in the first instance.

The Ambulance Services Council, which was established in 1983, is responsible for overseeing the co-ordination and development of ambulance services nationally and for the training of ambulance personnel. The chief executive officers of the health boards appoint the members of council for a three year term of office. The present council was appointed in October 1990.
I am very satisfied with the role played by the Ambulance Services Council and I have no proposals to establish a statutory body to carry out this task.

Qst.Quest: if she has any plans to make financial assistance available, either directly or indirectly to the school in Dungannon devoted to conductive education in order to enable persons from this country to avail of the services there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Cork Spastic School are currently making selective use of the conductive method in teaching a number of children and my Department have already provided support in this regard. I am currently having the work of this school reviewed and the question of whether further support is necessary will from part of this review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Length of School Term.

Qst.Quest: whether she has given consideration to lengthening the existing school term; her views on whether any benefits would arise through such action; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Primary Education Review Body examined the issues relating to the length of the school day and the school year. In their report, the review body recommended a model for the length of the primary school year based on schools operating for purposes of teaching for 184 days in the year.
In a detailed statement on the report of the review body, I said that I intended to implement this recommendation. This will be done by way of a circular letter.
Second level schools generally are required to be in operation for a minimum of 180 days each school year and this can include up to 12 days on which certificate examinations are held.

Qst.Quest: if she will consider extending the Cork Dental School, which has an intake of 35 students at present, to 70 which would meet the total national needs well into the future and obviate the necessity of making a large capital investment in another dental school in Dublin; and her views on whether, given that the Cork Dental School is the most modern one in the country, this course of action is in the interests of the taxpayer.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A decision will be taken by Government in due course on the question of providing a dental hospital/school in Dublin to replace the current dental hospital/school.
All aspects of the matter will be taken into account in arriving at that decision.

Qst.Quest: the number of temporary whole-time secondary teachers who are currently employed; if, in respect of these, she will outline (a) the number who have been employed to replace permanent teachers on maternity leave (b) the number who have been employed to replace permanent teachers on career breaks and (c) the other reasons temporary whole-time teachers are employed; and the number who are employed for each of these reasons.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy with regard to numbers of temporary whole-time teachers in secondary schools is not readily available in my Department.

However, while actual figures are not available, I can inform the Deputy in general terms that the vast majority of secondary teachers employed in a temporary whole-time capacity would be replacing teachers who are currently on career breaks. The balance would be required for other reasons — e.g. replacing teachers on extended, unpaid maternity leave; replacing teachers who are on secondment to an approved body; replacing teachers whose sick leave has expired but whose post is held for a period; and replacing teachers who are currently Members of the Oireachtas.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline by whom arrangements are being made to set up the committees to examine issues relating to children with learning difficulties; if she will further outline the persons who will be represented on the committees; and if she will invite individuals to make representations for inclusion on committees.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I take it the Deputy is referring to the special committee which is being established to review and make recommendations on educational provisions for children with special needs, as recommended by the Primary Education Review Body.
The chairman of the committee is Mr. Declan Brennan, former secretary of my Department.

The terms of reference of the committee are as follows: the identification of children with special needs and their assessment with a view to determining the educational provision best suited to the needs of each child; the arrangements which should be put in place in order to provide for the educational requirements of such children through complete or partial integration in ordinary school, through special classes in ordinary schools or through special schools or other special arrangements, in accordance with the circumstances as assessed of each child; the range of support services which may be required and in particular the future relationship between remedial teachers, visiting teachers, other support teachers and ordinary class teacher; and the linkages which should exist with other Departments of State and services provided under their aegis.

Arrangements to set up this committee are being finalised at present by my Department. The composition of the committee will be such as to reflect the wide range of interests in this area and will include representatives of parents, teachers, schools managements and specialists in the special education area, together with representatives of my Department.
I am sure the committee will be pleased to take submissions from all interested parties.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if she will outline (1) the number of primary school classes which have a pupil-teacher ratio of 25:1 or lower and (2) the number of primary school classes which will have a pupil-teacher ratio of 25:1 or lower on 1 September 1991.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, the overall pupil-teacher ratio will be reduced to 25:1 by September 1992. This will be achieved by retaining all existing posts in 1991 and 1992 and by creating 250 new posts in September 1991, and the balance required to achieve the 25:1 ratio in September 1992; this process will aim at reducing overly large classes and meeting the needs of the disadvantaged. The position will be reviewed at the end of 1993.
As the Deputy will also be aware the pupil-teacher ratio is obtained by dividing the number of teachers into the number of pupils enrolled in national schools.
The figure, provisional, for total enrolments in national schools on 30 September 1990 is 543,000. The total number of teachers at present is 20,447, giving an overall pupil-teacher ratio of 26.5:1.
Projected enrolment for September 1991 is 534,400. The estimated number of teachers is 20,700, giving an overall pupil-teacher ratio for the year 1991-92 of 25.8:1.
The overall pupil-teacher ratio includes, in addition to ordinary class teachers, administrative, non-teaching, principals, teachers in special schools and classes and remedial teachers.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the widespread anger in the parish of Williamstown, County Galway because of the lack of adequate school transport facilities to Williamstown national school; if her attention has further been drawn to the fact that some years ago when Williamstown became a central school, parents of children in the schools which were then closed were given a guarantee that their children would be entitled to free transport to the new school; if she will provide the same guarantee of transport to parents of the children in the Castletogher-Gurteen area of the parish as was heretofore the case; if her attention has further been drawn to the fact that the transport arrangements were not adequate before now and that the provision of the extra small bus, recently approved is totally inadequate; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware an additional bus was sanctioned for this service recently.
I am satisfied that all the eligible children attending Williamstown national school, including any from Gurteen-Castletogher, have a reasonable and adequate level of service.

In this case, as in all similar cases involving amalgamation, a letter was issued from the Department which confirmed the transport entitlement of the children from the closed school areas. The Department are honouring this guarantee in full in providing for all the eligible children.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Sligo School Amalgamation.

Qst.Quest: the present position of the new amalgamated national school in Ballymote, County Sligo which is to succeed the present girls' and boys' schools; if she will outline in particular, when work will start on the building; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The question of the placing of the contract for the Ballymote national school, County Sligo project is being considered in my Department and a decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mayo Regional Technical College.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline the Government's position on the provision of a regional technical college in Castlebar, County Mayo; whether Government support is still forthcoming for the concept; if she will further outline the progress which has been made since the Government took office in 1989; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will outline the progress which was made arising from her recent meeting with a deputation from Mayo Vocational Educational Committee concerning the introduction of third level courses to be held in Castlebar, County Mayo; if she has approved any such courses; if so, if she will outline the nature and extent of same; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 231 and 232 together.

I recently had a very useful meeting with a deputation from Mayo Vocational Education Committee. The deputation raised for consideration the provision of third level courses in Castlebar on an outcentre basis. The deputation said that they had some discussion with the health board with regard to the acquisition of part of a hospital in Castlebar for the purpose of accommodating the proposed outcentre provision. I told them that the relevant section in my Department would be asked to look at the building and to report on the matter.

With regard to course approval, any outcentre provision of courses would have to be under the aegis of a regional technical college and, therefore, the question of approval of specific courses does not arise at this time.

MainHeading.P: I will be keeping an active interest in this matter.

Qst.Quest: if her Department will consider providing free transport to all disabled people to post-primary schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department provides free transport on existing school transport services to post-primary pupils whose disability, having regard to the opinion of my Department's medical adviser, warrants the provision of school transport.

Qst.Quest: if the inquiry under way into the financial affairs of Kill national school, County Kildare will include (1) the board of management records and (2) the receipts of payments made to Kill national school by FÁS prior to January 1989; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I can assure the Deputy that all aspects that are considered relevant to the inquiry will be taken into account.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sligo Regional Technical College.

Qst.Quest: when it is intended to grant authorisation to Sligo regional technical college to start a degree course in quality assurance as sanctioned by the National Council for Education Awards; and whether the regional technical college will be in a position to commence the degree course in the next academic year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Proposals for the establishment of a degree course in quality assurance in Sligo regional technical college have been submitted to my Department by the Town of Sligo Vocational Education Committee.
The proposal is being considered in my Department and I hope to be in a position to communicate a decision to the vocational education committee in the near future.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that (a) at High Park national school, Skreen, County Sligo there is serious overcrowding because of the very limited classroom space available and (b) with 28 and 31 pupils in the two classrooms available, there is much less space available than the regulation of 15 square feet per pupil; and if, in view of all this, it is her intention to make arrangements for the necessary extra space to be provided in accordance with the request made to her by the board of management.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The school has three teachers and had an average enrolment of 98 in September 1990. Accommodation consists of a permanent building containing two classrooms provided in 1963 and an extension of a classroom and a staff room provided in 1988. My Department have no record of any application from the school authorities for the provision of additional classroom space at the school. If such an application is submitted it will be fully considered in consultation with my Department's professional staff.

In February 1990 the school authorities sought the provision of a general purposes room. However, it was not possible to accede to this because of my policy of conscentrating the available capital resources on the provision of essential classroom accommodation and other necessary facilities.

Qst.Quest: if she has received a request from the board of management of Lyrecrompane national school, County Kerry for her consent to the building of a utility/function room on the school grounds; and if she is prepared to accede to give approval as a matter of urgency.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department have only recently received a request from the authorities of Lyrecrompane national school, County Kerry for permission to build a community centre on the school site. This matter is being considered in my Department and a decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Grant Payments.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to any cases where local authority withheld or delayed payment, under section 7 of the Local Government (Financial Provisions) (No. 2) Act, 1983, of grant aid from her Department to qualifying third level students; if she will outline her views on this procedure; if she has issued, or proposes to issue directions to all local authorities concerning this unfair practice; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The position is that the administration of the higher education grants scheme is statutorily entrusted to local authorities and details of particular cases would not normally be available in my Department. It is understood that the Local Government Financial Provisions (No. 2) Act, 1983 provides a local authority with the power to set off amounts owing by it to a person against amounts due by that person to the authority in respect of a charge.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Schools Staffing.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she will outline the arrangements she is making for schools which are only marginally short for the allocation of an extra teacher, such as a school (details supplied) in Dublin 3 where the lack of the extra teacher will cause considerable disruption to classes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware the staffing of national schools for a particular year is determined by the enrolment in the school on 30 September of the previous year. This is in accordance with the agreement between the Government and INTO under the Programme for National Recovery.

MainHeading.P: In the case of Eoin Baisde Senior Girls national school there were 449 pupils enrolled on 30 September 1990, which warrants a staff of principal plus 13 assistants for the 1991-92 school year. The school will also have the services of a full-time remedial teacher.

The only exceptions that can be made to the agreed staffing arrangements are in the case of developing schools or where my Department's guidelines on maximum class sizes are being breached. If the school authorities feel that the school may qualify under either of these exceptions my Department will be happy to examine any application received.

Qst.Quest: if the proposal to build a new second level community school in Castlerea, County Roscommon will be released to tender within the next two weeks in order that construction of the new school can commence immediately as use of the present buildings cease on completion of exams at the centre this term.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A list of interested contractors who will be invited to tender for the proposed community school in Castlerea, County Roscommon has been prepared and the tender documents for the project are being processed at present.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Defence Forces Allocation to Border Area.

Qst.Quest: the manpower of our Defence Forces which is allocated to Border duties; and if he will outline the cost implications of these duties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Daly) Minister for Defence (Mr. Daly)
Speaker.P: In the interests of security it is not the practice to furnish information relating to the strength or deployment of the Defence Forces involved in particular operations. The cost of Border security is not separately compiled.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cork Barracks, Surgical Unit.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the position of the staff attached to the surgical unit in Collins Barracks, Cork after 1 June 1991; and if, before making the decision to shut the unit, he will consider the inconvenience of transporting personnel needing surgical care to Dublin or the Curragh and also the inconvenience to their families who would wish to visit them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Daly) Minister for Defence (Mr. Daly)
Speaker.P: In the interests of efficiency and economy it has been decided that surgical procedures under general anaesthetic should be discontinued at the Military Hospital, Collins Barracks, Cork. In recent years, surgery carried out at the hospital has generally been of a minor nature only.
With effect from 1 June 1991, members of the Permanent Defence Force in the Cork area who require surgical treatment will in general be treated in local civilian hospitals.

The only staff of the hospital affected by the decision referred to above is one member of the Army nursing service. In that regard it is envisaged that for the foreseeable future the person in question will be assigned to other duties in the hospital.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Road Haulage Competency Certificate.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: when an application by a person (details supplied) in County Wicklow for a certificate of professional competence in road haulage which was submitted over two years ago will be decided upon; the reason for the delay in this case; his views on whether the efforts of an entrepreneurial type of small operator to create jobs in one of the most economically depressed areas of the country should be afforded this poor level of support; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: The European Communities (Merchandise Road Transport) Regulations, 1988 included a provision under which persons who could prove that they either operated or managed a lawful merchandise road transport business prior to 1 January 1975, could qualify for a certificate of competence on the basis of this experience.

The person named in the question applied under this provision, but the evidence submitted was insufficient to support the application. Accordingly, a certificate of competence could not be granted in this case. I should add that there has been protracted correspondence between the applicant and my Department in this matter.
